text: Verses 7 through 10 is a familiar passage of Scripture to many of God's people. In fact, it's one that perhaps you've heard someone preach on, you've heard somebody reference the portion of Scripture. Maybe you have even memorized part of this passage that I'm gonna preach this morning. I believe this morning that the truth that is contained within this passage is a truth that it's imperative that every child of God truly understands and grasps this truth. We notice in verse number seven, I'm actually gonna back up and look at verse number six, five, sorry, in verse number five, notice what Paul says. He says, of such in one will I glory, yet of myself I will not glory, but in mine infirmities. For though I would desire to glory, I should not be a fool. For I will say the truth, but now I forbear, lest any man should think of me above that which he seeth me to be, or that he heareth of me. So in the first six verses, I only read the last couple of them, verse five and six, we find that Paul is referencing some visions, according to verse number one, that he, visions and revelations that are received of the Lord. But it wasn't only glory in those things, but we find that Paul was privileged to see and to have those visions and revelations. He also mentions in the text of Scripture that he was not able, it was unlawful for him to speak or to utter these things. And many times I've heard people through the years say, someone had this vision or someone had this experience. And so we must be careful, we must understand the truth of 1 John to try the spirits. But notice, with understanding all these revelations and visions that Paul received, he starts in verse seven and says, and lest I should be exalted above measure through the abundance of the revelations, notice, there was given to me a thorn in the flesh. Now, this isn't really part of the message or the bulk of the message this morning, but I want you to consider what Paul says in verse number seven. He says, there was given to me a thorn in the flesh. I want you to acknowledge that Paul recognized this morning that this thorn in the flesh that he references, it was given to him. It was on purpose, it had a purpose, it was given to him by God. And Paul recognized that. Listen, nothing in your life happens by accident. Nothing in my life happens by accident. We find that God is in control of all things. We find that God was giving to Paul this thorn in the flesh. Notice it says, the messenger of Satan to buffet me, lest I should be exalted above measure. Now notice in verse eight, for this thing, for what thing, this thorn in the flesh, I besought the Lord thrice that it might depart from me. So Paul prayed on three different occasions, specifically prayed that this would be removed, that he says that it might be depart from me, that it might depart from me. Have you ever had a situation, you pray and you ask God that it would depart from you? Come on, we pray, God, would you help this thing depart from me, right? I don't wanna deal with this thing. I don't wanna deal with this infirmity. I don't wanna have this issue. I don't wanna have this problem. I don't want this heartache. I don't want this obstacle. Are you with me this morning? You pray that God would remove it. By the way, aren't you thankful that God can remove it? Amen, you pray that he would remove it because you know that he has the power to do so. But we find this morning that sometimes as we look at our text this morning, it is not always within the will of God that he will remove from your life or my life, what we desire for him to remove from our lives. Now, it doesn't mean that he cannot. It simply means that it's not within his will. It means that he has a greater purpose in that thing than maybe we understand or recognize at the particular moment. We can look through the gospel records. We can see as the Lord Jesus Christ is walking upon the face of the earth in his earthly ministry, and we can see many times in which God healed and God performed miracles, but we find that there were certain times in which God led his people directly into difficulty to prove himself and to increase their faith. And this morning, we find that Paul, because he understood the power of God, because he experienced the work of God in his life, he prays that God would remove this thing from his life, this thorn in the flesh. He says, I besought the Lord. Listen, this is earnest prayer. This wasn't just a passing, Lord, would you? No, he's earnestly seeking, he's beseeching the Lord that it might depart from me. And I want you to notice in verse number nine, and he, that's God, said unto me, that's Paul, my grace is sufficient for thee, for my strength is made perfect in weakness. We find that God replies, responds to the request of Paul, according to verse number eight, that he would remove this thing from his life, and God's response is given to us in verse number nine, and there are two elements to this promise that are explained to us, and I want you to notice number one. It's very simple truth, but it says, number one, my grace is sufficient for thee. I'm thankful this morning to know the grace of God. I'm thankful this morning to have experienced the grace of God.
